body:
Comment 10: 
the binary distribution is to satisfy the most *common* usage of Go, and
you've agreed that most windows Go user don't need the cross compilation
capabilities.

if we include 386 toolchain (should we include 386 packages?) in the msi
package and set the precedence, there will be a lot more problems to solve.

for example, should we also consider to add this to the other binary distri-
butions? i.e. should darwin-amd64.pkg contain 386 toolchains? should
darwin-386.pkg contain amd64 toolchains?

some people will argue that providing arm toolchain in linux tarballs will be
similarly helpful, should we do that?

furthermore, given Go's excellent cross compilation capabilities, why not
just release one download that contains binaries for all supported systems
so that people only ever need to download one file, and could build binaries
for all supported system?

where should we draw the line?
